skill.name: brainstorming
skill.description: You MUST use this before any creative work - creating features, building components, adding functionality, or modifying behavior. Explores user intent, requirements and design before implementation.
skill.summary: Collaborative design methodology for exploring ideas through natural dialogue before implementation begins.
skill.author: Cygnusfear

security_audit.summary: All 21 static findings evaluated as false positives. The static analyzer incorrectly flagged benign documentation text including git commands, file paths, and software methodology terms as security issues. This is a pure planning/methodology skill that only facilitates collaborative design discussions through dialogue. No code execution, network requests, or cryptographic operations exist.

content.value_statement: Teams often jump straight into implementation without clarifying requirements, leading to rework and missed expectations. This skill guides collaborative brainstorming sessions that explore intent, constraints, and alternatives before any code is written.
actual_capabilities: Asks clarifying questions one at a time to understand project context and requirements
Proposes 2-3 different design approaches with trade-offs and recommendations
Presents designs in sections of 200-300 words with incremental validation
Documents validated designs to markdown files in docs/plans directory
Creates git commits for design documents
Sets up isolated workspaces for implementation using git worktrees
limitations: Does not execute code or modify project files outside of documentation
Does not access external APIs or network resources
Does not generate implementation code directly
Relies on user input to refine requirements and validate design sections

use_cases.title: New Feature Definition
use_cases.description: Product managers use this to define new features by answering focused questions about user needs, constraints, and success criteria before development begins.

use_cases.title: Technical Design Review
use_cases.description: Software architects use this to explore alternative approaches, document architectural decisions, and validate designs with stakeholders incrementally.

use_cases.title: Refactoring Planning
use_cases.description: Developers use this to plan refactoring efforts by understanding current state, defining target state, and identifying risks before changing code.

prompt_templates.title: Quick Feature Request
prompt_templates.prompt: I want to add [feature description] to the project. What questions do you have to understand what I'm trying to accomplish?

prompt_templates.title: Architecture Exploration
prompt_templates.prompt: We need to design a [system component]. What approaches should we consider and what are the trade-offs of each?

prompt_templates.title: Constraint Identification
prompt_templates.prompt: What constraints should I tell you about before we design [feature]? Include performance, security, and timeline constraints.

prompt_templates.title: Design Validation Review
prompt_templates.prompt: Here is my design section for [component]. Does this look right given our earlier discussion about requirements?

output_examples.input: I want to add a dark mode toggle to the settings page
output: Great! Let me understand what you're trying to accomplish.
First question: How should the toggle work?
A) A switch in the settings menu that persists to localStorage
B) Auto-detect system preference and follow OS settings
C) Match the current time (light during day, dark at night)

output_examples.input: We need to build a file upload component
output: I've noted that. Now, what's the primary use case?
A) User profile pictures (small, single file)

output_examples.input: Ready to set up for implementation
output: Here's what we've designed so far:
- SettingsToggle: React component with localStorage persistence
- useDarkMode: Custom hook for theme state management
- ThemeProvider: Context wrapper for theme application
Does this architecture look correct before we proceed?

best_practices: Start by understanding the project context before asking requirements questions
Ask one question per message to avoid overwhelming users
Use multiple choice questions when possible to speed up decision making
Present design in small sections and validate each before continuing
anti_patterns: Asking multiple questions in a single message
Skipping the clarification phase and jumping straight to implementation
Designing features without considering YAGNI (You Aren't Gonna Need It)
Presenting the entire design at once without incremental validation

faq.question: When should I use this skill?
faq.answer: Use this before any creative work: creating features, building components, adding functionality, or modifying behavior. It is designed for the planning phase before implementation.

faq.question: Does this skill write code?
faq.answer: No. This skill focuses on collaborative design through dialogue. It documents designs to markdown files and may set up git worktrees, but it does not generate implementation code.

faq.question: How long should a brainstorming session be?
faq.answer: Sessions vary based on complexity. For simple features, a few exchanges may suffice. For complex systems, multiple sessions may be needed. The skill validates incrementally to ensure alignment.

faq.question: What if I do not know the answers to the questions?
faq.answer: That is expected. The skill helps stakeholders discover their requirements through guided questions. Answer what you can and indicate uncertainty where it exists.

faq.question: Can I continue from a previous session?
faq.answer: Yes. The skill reads recent commits and design documents to understand context. You can reference previous discussions by mentioning them.

faq.question: What happens after the design is complete?
faq.answer: The skill documents the design to docs/plans, commits it to git, and asks if you want to set up for implementation using git worktrees.
